title: ASX to slide; BHP production declines
text:
Vesna Poljak

Hamish Douglass says in his portfolio, he holds no banking stocks.

"I'm not enamoured if I look out the next decade that banks are the right place to put your money."

The technology sector is only 4 per cent of the Australian market versus banks at around 25 per cent.

Magellan chairman Hamish Douglass. Peter Rae

There are "wonderful" opportunities in and outside of China, Douglass continues. More on that later.

Andrew Clifford recalls minus 0.7 per cent yields on German bunds.

The problem this is creating is it's forcing investors to look elsewhere, including equities - but at a time when there's lots of things making it difficult to be an equity investor.

But he reckons this market is throwing up a lot of opportunities: "rather than trying to solve those worries and they're always there... make sure you're not with the crowd."

Interest rates are the greatest dilemma for any investor right now, Douglass says.

"What long-term interest rate should I be assuming in my valuation of stocks?"

Probably not zero, but equities would look cheap were that the case. An appropriate discount rate would be around 3 per cent at Magellan.

"It's pushing people into riskier assets because central banks are pushing this whole equation to zero or negative."

Some material inflation in the US, above 2 per cent and wages around 4, would see a violent correction to asset prices.

Andrew Clifford says this belief about zero interest rates is a very very strong consensus amongst investors.

It's not about if they will be zero or negative but when.

"Here's the problem, we've already re-rated the stocks for low interest rates... this is history now. If interest rates go to zero, there will probably still be people drawn into the market [and it might still go higher] but the big risk is the opposite."

If we get co-ordinated fiscal spend "maybe that will be it".

"Australia is unique, we had this interesting discussion about banks not passing on the [rate cut]," Clifford says.

Most banking businesses are about getting deposits through the door.

European banks are trading at half book value or below, he says, and some of them are actually terrific businesses.
description: Australian shares are poised to slide; Resource stocks report quarterly results; Hamish Douglass, Andrew Clifford at Morningstar conference; Jobs figures ahead.
